data.text: @PenguinJunk @dpeilow The argument against #HS2 on the grounds of habitat destruction is quite thin when you pick through the exaggerated claims of anti-HS2 campaigners. For the whole Phase 1/2a schemes, 39ha of ancient woodland are lost, vs a UK total of 364,000ha.... https://t.co/QNv2LQIz1Y

data.text: @dpeilow @PenguinJunk You also need to define "London" which has 6 airports. The addressable market for #HS2 is the catchment area of Euston/OOC. This is far smaller than the catchment of 6 airports serving the whole SE. The journey time savings don't apply to much of the domestic air market

text: @dpeilow @PenguinJunk You also need to define "London" which has 6 airports. The addressable market for #HS2 is the catchment area of Euston/OOC. This is far smaller than the catchment of 6 airports serving the whole SE. The journey time savings don't apply to much of the domestic air market

data.text: @dpeilow @PenguinJunk The Channel is entirely relevant to comparing journey options between London and Scotland and London and Paris. I'm amazed this needs to be said. At best #HS2 improves Lon/Gla by 49 minutes, Lon/Ed by about 20 minutes once the promised faster services are introduced

text: @dpeilow @PenguinJunk The Channel is entirely relevant to comparing journey options between London and Scotland and London and Paris. I'm amazed this needs to be said. At best #HS2 improves Lon/Gla by 49 minutes, Lon/Ed by about 20 minutes once the promised faster services are introduced

data.text: @NigelSarbutts @PenguinJunk The approved phases of HS2 speed up London to Scotland trains by an hour. Again, the point of the thread is to show that will produce a well documented modal shift away from air on one of Europe's busiest air routes, with the associated carbon benefits. The Channel is irrelevant.

data.text: @dpeilow @PenguinJunk You put a lot of emphasis in your argument on HS1 impact on Lon/Paris flights. There is no #HS2 analogy with Lon/Scotland flights for the obvious reasons that we already have good rail connections and don't have a Channel to cross https://t.co/g0oTE2AHso

data.text: @dpeilow @PenguinJunk That's because they are the current statements of #HS2 Ph1 and 2A emissions. When you say "If Phase 1 and 2a are together negative" and then leap to concluding therefore 2B would be too, you are ignoring/misinterpreting what the analysis by HS2 says.

text: @dpeilow @PenguinJunk That's because they are the current statements of #HS2 Ph1 and 2A emissions. When you say "If Phase 1 and 2a are together negative" and then leap to concluding therefore 2B would be too, you are ignoring/misinterpreting what the analysis by HS2 says.

data.text: @NigelSarbutts @PenguinJunk You revert to E10/E27 every time. The point of the thread is to show the model that produced them ignores modal shift from Scottish flights, over estimates grid emissions and overestimates energy use. 2b is irrelevant to London-Scotland flights, but that it is also -ve is a bonus

data.text: @dpeilow @PenguinJunk Then the thread makes no sense because you're ignoring what E10 & E27 say and omitting 2B emissions, which you justify by restating something demonstrably false about what E10 and E27 say about #HS2 being carbon positive. It's a circular argument where every step is wrong.

text: @dpeilow @PenguinJunk Then the thread makes no sense because you're ignoring what E10 & E27 say and omitting 2B emissions, which you justify by restating something demonstrably false about what E10 and E27 say about #HS2 being carbon positive. data.text: @NigelSarbutts @PenguinJunk Yes - which is stated in the thread. If Phase 1 and 2a are together negative and then when Phase 2b is authorised it produces more modal shift and itself is negative, the end result is that the whole scheme is more negative and still pays back quicker.

text: @NigelSarbutts @PenguinJunk Yes - which is stated in the thread. If Phase 1 and 2a are together negative and then when Phase 2b is authorised it produces more modal shift and itself is negative, the end result is that the whole scheme is more negative and still pays back quicker.

data.text: @NigelSarbutts @PenguinJunk I don't - I state it is based on the Phase 1 and 2a scheme underway. If Phase 1 and 2a are in fact carbon negative in ¼ the time claimed and Phase 2b is also carbon negative, then it stands to reason the whole scheme is carbon negative.

data.text: @NigelSarbutts @PenguinJunk The calculations deal with the 120 years which appears in the Phase 1 hybrid bill of 2017 and been latched onto since. That is shown in the 2nd tweet. I am not aware of data showing Ph 2b is the most carbon intensive. In fact the opposite. 2b documentation shows a net reduction. https://t.co/Iaq27Fxn1i

data.text: @PenguinJunk @dpeilow I can't see where in that thread emissions from Ph2B (the most CO2 intensive phase of #HS2) are included in the calculation of payback. If they are missing, all the numbers that follow are wrong.
